questions.text: A 23-year-old lady presents with the lesions shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown are cold sores, also known as herpes labialis caused by Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). Herpes labialis primarily affects the lip and typically present as thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down with superficial ulcers. They generally heal without scarring.

HSV-1 can be isolated from lesions in and around the mouth and is transmitted by direct contact or droplet spread from cases or carriers. HSV-2 is responsible for the majority of genital herpes infections and is commonly transmitted venereally.

The images below show lesions of herpes labialis. 

Related Pearl: Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus

  1. Cutaneous lesions: Fever blister, herpetic whitlow, herpetic gladiatorum, eczema herpeticum. Eczema herpeticum is a generalised eruption caused by Herpes infections in children suffering from eczema
  2. Mucosal: most common site involved is buccal mucosa. It may cause Gingivostomatitis & Pharyngitis, Recurrent herpes labialis.
  3. Ophthalmic: Follicular conjunctivitis and acute keratoconjunctivitis also occur. 
  4. Nervous System: HSV encephalitis, HSV meningitis.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in:
questions.solution:
Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex infection 

The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HSV, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

  • Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies

Vaccinia, variola (smallpox) Guarnieri bodies
Variola (smallpox) Paschen bodies
Molluscum contagiosum Henderson-Patterson bodies
Fowlpox Bollinger bodies
  • Intra-nuclear Inclusion Bodies 
  Inclusion bodies  Disease/Virus

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has had 4 episodes of meningitis over the last 4 years, with the disease lasting a few days at a time, leaving slowly resolving neurological symptoms such as visual and memory loss. A CSF cytology shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and a diagnosis of Mollaret’s meningitis is made. Which organism is implicated here?
questions.solution: Mollaret’s meningitis or benign recurrent lymphocytic meningitis is most commonly caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). Demonstration of HSV antibodies in CSF or persistence of HSV DNA in CSF can establish the diagnosis.

questions.text: A dentist presents to the surgery OPD with the findings shown below. He is febrile. Microscopic examination of the tissue reveals Tzanck cells. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The image suggests herpetic whitlow, confirmed by the presence of Tzanck cells on microscopy. It is caused by HSV-1.

It is often contracted by health care workers that come in contact with the virus when exposed to oral secretions.

On Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, Tzanck cells are seen. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin. Tzanck smear is also used in the diagnosis of Hailey-Hailey disease, Darier’s disease, hand-foot-and-mouth disease, etc.

Diagnosis of herpes simplex virus:

  • Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can differentiate between HSV 1 and 2)
  • Most definitive test- virus isolation using human diploid fibroblast in which cytopathic changes can be observed as early as 24 - 48 hours.
  • Microscopy - Tzanck smear is prepared by Wright or Giemsa stain. Intranuclear type A inclusion bodies may be seen in Giemsa-stained smears.

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Clusters of vesicles are seen on an erythematous base along with painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy suggest a diagnosis of genital herpes. Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells are present on microscopy.

The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive, and inexpensive diagnostic method.  Smears are prepared from the lesions, from the base of vesicles, and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground glass chromatin -  Tzanck cells are seen.

The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers. They heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneous lesions in the face - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead.

 

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

questions.text: Your neighbor’s child complains of fever and develops a rash. On examination, the rashes are present all over the body, and look like ‘dewdrops lying on the skin’. The child says that his friend in school had similar complaints a few days ago. Which of the given statements is true about this rash?

choices.text: The rash usually starts on the distal parts of limbs
All the lesions are of same age
Scabs are also infectious in chicken pox

questions.solution:
The condition described here is chickenpox. It is caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The following are the characteristics of rash seen in chicken pox :

  • The rash is centripetal in distribution. 
  • It evolves rapidly, progressing through macule, papule, vesicle, pustule, and finally scab.
  • It is a pleomorphic rash and appears in crops, hence varying stages of lesions can be noticed at a given time.
  • The lesions resemble a dewdrop lying on the skin, as they are superficial and do not involve the deeper layers of the skin.

 

Related Pearl: Differentiating Features between Smallpox and Chickenpox

 

 

Smallpox (Variola)

 

Chickenpox (Varicella)

Incubation Period 

7–17 days

14–21 days

Transmission

Respiratory viral shedding  

Through contact with the fluid found in the patient's sores. 

Rarely airborne route.

Aerosolized droplets from nasopharyngeal secretions.

By direct cutaneous contact with vesicle fluid from skin lesions.

Airborne transmission rarely

Prodrome 

Fever and malaise for 2–4 days before onset of rash

Minimal to none

 

Rash

centrifugal spread

Usually on palms and soles

Axilla is usually free

Rash on extensor surfaces

centripetal distribution

Seldom on palms and soles; appears in crops

Axilla affected

Rash on flexor surfaces

Pock Appearance

Vesicular  > pustular  >

umbilicated >scab

Macule > Papule > Vesicular on erythematous

Base >pustular >scab

Evolution of Pocks

Synchronous

Asynchronous

Scab Formation

10–14 days after onset of rash

4–7 days after onset of rash

Scab Separation

14–28 days after onset of rash

Within 14 days after onset of rash

Infectivity

From onset of exanthem until all scabs separate

 From 1 day before rash until all vesicles become scab. Scabs are non-infectious.

questions.text: While on rounds in the NICU, you notice a newborn baby with a zig-zag dermatomal cicatrix on the forehead and left side of the face. The limbs are small and atrophied. Microcephaly is noted. Which maternal infection are these findings characteristically associated with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital varicella syndrome. Hence, an antenatal history of varicella zoster virus (VZV) infection would be significant in the mother of this baby.

Fetal varicella infection occurs if the mother gets infected during the first half of pregnancy.

Clinical features include:

  • Cicatrix, a zigzag scarring in a dermatomal distribution
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cataracts
  • Optic atrophy
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microcephaly
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Motor and sensory deficits

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients one to four months following transplantation?
questions.solution:
The predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients are fever (common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. 

JC virus and BK virus are common infections after solid organ transplantation based on the site of infection. This means BK and JC viruses are the most common organisms to infect the kidney after any solid organ transplant. But CMV is the predominant organism to cause infection in a person who has undergone a renal transplant. (Not the most common organism to affect the kidney after any solid organ transplant). 

Because of the frequency and severity of CMV disease, antiviral prophylaxis with ganciclovir or valganciclovir is being used in renal transplant recipients whenever indicated to prevent CMV disease.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his worried parents with a rash and yellowish discoloration of the skin. On examination, the baby has petechiae, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and microcephaly. The developmental assessment shows global developmental delay. An axial cut of the non-contrast CT of the brain is given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and imaging suggest a diagnosis of congenital CMV infection. The non-contrast CT head shows periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly.

Features of congenital CMV infection: 

  • Petechial rash
  • Jaundice
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Microcephaly
  • Deafness
  • Chorioretinitis
  • IUGR
  • Periventricular calcification and ventriculomegaly

 

Option A: Congenital rubella syndrome is a triad of cardiac defects, cataracts, and congenital hearing loss.

Option B: Neonatal herpes presents as skin lesions with eye involvement, encephalitis, and disseminated disease.

Option D: Fetal varicella syndrome is manifested as cicatrizing/scarring skin lesions, chorioretinitis, hypoplastic limbs, low birth weight, and CNS defects due to cerebral atrophy.

Note: In 15-20% of infants with congenital CMV infection, microcephaly is not detected at birth. It may develop as the child grows and is detected at follow-up visits for other complaints.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV.

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.solution:
Resistance to ganciclovir most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. 

Option B: Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the host.

Option C: CMV infection is mostly subclinical.

Option D: UL54 mutations can confer resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir, and foscarnet.

questions.text: Where are owl's eye inclusion bodies seen?
questions.solution:
Owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

questions.text: What does the Paul-Bunnell test diagnose?
questions.solution:
Paul-Bunnell test is used to diagnose kissing disease (infectious mononucleosis) caused by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).

It is a heterophile agglutination test used to identify the heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep erythrocytes. Patients suffering from infectious mononucleosis due to Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) will produce antibodies that will react and agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text:
You are studying the association of human herpesvirus-4 with other diseases. Which of the following patients have diseases associated with this virus?
  1. A college student with infectious mononucleosis
  2. An African child with Burkitt’s lymphoma
  3. A 60-year-old tobacco chewer with oral submucous fibrosis
  4. A middle-aged man with adult T-cell leukemia 
  5. An HIV-positive man with hairy leukoplakia
questions.solution:
Human herpesvirus-4 or Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt’s lymphoma, and is associated with oral hairy leukoplakia in HIV patients. 

EBV may cause the following malignancies:

  • Burkitt’s lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (in people of Chinese origin),
  • Lymphomas in immunodeficient persons such as AIDS or transplant recipients.

Endemic or African Burkitt's lymphoma has got nearly 100% association with EBV, as compared to non-endemic and HIV-associated Burkitt's lymphoma. 

Oral hairy leukoplakia is triggered by EBV in patients with poor immune status, most commonly with HIV. 

Oral submucous fibrosis is associated with the human papillomavirus (HPV). 

Adult T cell leukemia is associated with the human T-cell leukemia virus.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is known to cause hemorrhagic cystitis, diarrhea, and conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus is known to cause hemorrhagic cystitis, diarrhea, and conjunctivitis.

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis in children is caused by adenoviruses types 11 and 21.

The following table shows various syndromes caused by adenoviruses and associated serotypes:

Syndrome Adenovirus serotypes
Respiratory disease in children 1, 2, 5, 6
Sore throat, febrile cold, pneumonia 3, 4, 7, 14, 21
ARD in military recruits 4, 7, 21
Follicular (swimming pool) conjunctivitis/ Pharyngoconjunctival fever 3, 7
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (shipyard eye) 8, 19, 37
Diarrhea 40, 41

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is:
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 infection mimics erythroblastosis fetalis. 

Parvovirus B19 is associated with: 

  1. Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)
  2. Transient aplastic crisis
  3. Pure red cell aplasia
  4. Erythroblastosis fetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy)

Picornavirus, Epstein-Barr virus, HSV infection do not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

questions.text: Which organism causes the disease shown below?
questions.solution:
The image showed a rash on the cheeks and face, with a slapped cheek appearance, characteristic of erythema infectiosum/ fifth disease. It is caused by Parvovirus B19.

Parvovirus B19 usually presents as a respiratory infection, with an erythematous maculopapular rash and arthralgia. The rash starts as prominent erythema of the cheek, popularly known as slapped-cheek appearance. The rash further spreads to the trunk and limbs followed by lymphadenopathy and arthralgia.

It induces aplastic crisis in sickle cell anemia patients.

Infection during pregnancy leads to non-immune fetal hydrops (highest risk in the first half of gestational period).

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with skin lesions, suspected to be molluscum contagiosum. How is the diagnosis of this condition typically made?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum is based on clinical appearance.

Molluscum contagiosum manifests as pink pearly wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center (umbilicated), not associated with inflammation and necrosis.

Option B: Skin biopsy or smear of expressed material shows characteristic inclusion bodies but is necessary only when the diagnosis is uncertain.

Options A and C: Viral culture and PCR for viral DNA are not used for diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows condyloma acuminata. It is most commonly caused by Human papillomavirus (HPV) 6 and 11.

Condyloma acuminata is a benign, genital wart which is a moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia. 

Microscopically, the characteristic features include:

  • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma
  • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening)
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is characteristic of HPV infection.
  • No evident dysplasia

Option A: Treponema pallidum can cause condylomata lata in secondary syphilis. It is smoother and flatter and may be associated with induration and ulceration. (image below)

Option C: Human papillomavirus 16 and 18 are associated with carcinoma of the cervix and anogenital region.

Option D: Hemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid. Given below is the image of chancroid.

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 1,2,3,4
  • Common warts (verruca vulgaris, plantar wart)
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: A patient presents with plantar warts as shown below. Which type of human papillomavirus is responsible for causing these?
questions.solution:
HPV types 1a, 57, and 27 accounts for most plantar warts.

HPV 7 causes hand warts in butchers (butcher's warts).

HPV 6 and 11 cause condyloma acuminata, sinonasal papilloma, and squamous papilloma of the larynx. 

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV 16

questions.text: As a CHC medical officer, you organize an outreach program for HPV vaccination and the prevention of cervical cancer. Which protein is used for antigenic response in this vaccine?
questions.solution:
The HPV vaccines use virus-like particles (VLPs) that consist of the HPV L1 major capsid protein. The L1 protein self-assembles into VLPs when expressed in eukaryotic cells.

These VLPs contain the same epitopes as the HPV virion. But they do not contain genetic material and cannot transmit infection. The immunogenicity of the HPV vaccines relies on the development of conformational neutralizing antibodies to epitopes displayed on viral capsids.

The nonavalent HPV vaccine works against strains 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. It is usually commercialized in the name of Gardasil-9. It has received expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers. 

HPV Vaccine  Types
Quadrivalent (Gardasil)

6, 11, 16, 18
Bivalent (Cervarix) 16, 18
Nonavalent (Gardasil-9) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

questions.text: Nonavalent HPV vaccine works against which of the following strains of the virus?
questions.solution:
The nonavalent HPV vaccine works against strains 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. It is usually commercialized in the name of Gardasil-9. It has received expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and other head and neck cancers. 

HPV Vaccine  Types

Quadrivalent (Gardasil)

6, 11, 16, 18
Bivalent (Cervarix) 16, 18
Nonavalent (Gardasil-9) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following skin lesions. Which of the following diseases is associated with the virus implicated here?
questions.solution:
The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques in an HIV-positive patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8. It also causes primary effusion lymphoma. It is one of seven currently known human cancer viruses or oncoviruses.

 HHV-8 or Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is known to cause Kaposi’s sarcoma, in immunocompromised persons. Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, AIDS patients, and organ transplant recipients are all at a high risk of showing signs of infection.

KSHV is a known causative agent of four diseases:

  1. Kaposi's sarcoma
  2. KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD)
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma
  4. KSHV inflammatory cytokine syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is implicated in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is caused by the JC virus. JC virus-induced progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is one of the neurologic diseases associated with HIV infection.

Option B: BK virus is associated with nephropathy in transplant recipients.

Option C: The long-term sequelae associated with measles infection is subacute sclerosing panencephalitis.

Option D: Herpes simplex virus causes temporal lobe encephalitis.
